source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The investigation showed that the strength of the Zircaloy-2 decreased by 50 percent between room temperature and 400 C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: To maintain adequate ductility above 200 C in hydrided Zircaloy-2 tubing tested under biaxial stress, it is necessary to specify an upper limit in the region of 400 ppm for hydrogen content

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The least ductile condition cold is with an external hydride layer present

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: the ductility can be significantly improved if this layer is absorbed entirely into the tube wall

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: the critical threshold for hydrogen embrittlement can be raised from 70 to 450 ppm H2 in the tube wall

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Ring tension tests are not as sensitive to hydride embrittlement as the biaxially stressed tube-burst test

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Platelets oriented nearly perpendicular to the deforming tensile stress caused large reductions in strength and ductility when cold at small hydrogen concentrations (~50 ppm)

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Platelets oriented nearly perpendicular to the deforming tensile stress caused large reductions in strength and ductility when cold at small hydrogen concentrations (~50 ppm)

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: platelets oriented nearly parallel to the stress axis had relatively little effect up to ~500 ppm H2

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: tube-burst tests under biaxial stress conditions on Zircaloy-2 containing circumferentially aligned hydride at ~70 ppm hydrogen internal level, together with an external layer of hydride, have shown circumferential strains to failure of only 1.5 percent at room temperature
specimen_state: circumferentially aligned hydride with external layer

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Two methods of hydriding were used: electrolytic with a diffusion anneal for levels up to ~450 ppm H2; and heating in an aqueous LiOH solution for the higher levels of hydrogen

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The tubes were finally stress relieved at 515 C for 6 h

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The asreceived tubing has a hydrogen content between 20 and 25 ppm

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: when hydrided, all the tubing had a very high degree (~95 percent) of circumferentially-aligned hydride

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The tubing was then electrolytically hydrided at 90±3 C in a dilute solution of H2SO4 in H2O

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The time of electrolytic hydriding was varied between 16 and 48 h to give thicker hydride layers and hence progressively increasing hydrogen levels in the tube after heating

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: at the upper levels (450 ppm H2), some of the hydrogen may still be present as a thin external layer not fully absorbed into the tube

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: tubes were heated in an autoclave containing an aqueous LiOH solution (48 g/liter) at a temperature of 283 C and a pressure of 1000 psi

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: Closed-end tube-burst specimens were prepared from 6-in. long tube with welded end plugs and a small capillary tube leading to the pressure connections. The heat-affected zones of the welds were protected by Zircaloy collars.
process_step: welded end plugs, Zircaloy collar protection

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: Stainless-steel inserts were used to reduce the volume of free space, thereby reducing the amount of stored energy released on fracture from the compressed gas. This was necessary to avoid shattering the specimens on failure in the lower temperature range (up to 175 C).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: The tubes were burst in a direct resistance heating rig with the specimen held at its ends between water-cooled copper clamps. Temperature was measured by a 0.010-in. chromel-alumel thermocouple attached to the center of the gage length. The specimens were heated rapidly to the test temperature, held for 15 min to stabilize the specimen structure, and pressurized internally with argon using an intensifier. Room-temperature tests were carried out with a hydraulic intensifier using oil as the pressurizing fluid.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: The burst strength was calculated from the formula, σ_c = P D / 2 t where: σ_c = circumferential hoop stress to failure, psi, P = internal pressure, D = average internal diameter, in., and t = average wall thickness, in.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: The tensile strength decreased with temperature, giving a reduction of 50 percent from room temperature to 400 C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: The effect on strength of increasing the hydrogen content to 340 ppm H2 was negligible, and both the unhydrided and hydrided data could be plotted on the same curve.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: A slight increase in strength was found at the 460-ppm H2 level.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: Specimens up to 460 ppm H2 had total elongation values which increased with temperature but tended to level off between 300 and 400 C

evidence_span: Specimens up to 460 ppm H2 had total elongation values which increased with temperature but tended to level off between 300 and 400 C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: The specimens did not exhibit any embrittlement at room temperature although there was a reduction in ductility from 17.5 percent for the unhydrided tube to 13 percent for the 460-ppm H2 specimen.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: The specimens did not exhibit any embrittlement at room temperature although there was a reduction in ductility from 17.5 percent for the unhydrided tube to 13 percent for the 460-ppm H2 specimen.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: The effect of hydrogen was to reduce ductility at all temperatures but not to a drastic extent.

evidence_span: At 820 ppm H2, the specimens were completely embrittled from room temperature up to 150 C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: As with the ring tension tests, the strength of the Zircaloy-2 is decreased by 50 percent from room temperature to 400 C.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: The strength of the hydrided tube (460 ppm H2) was greater than the unhydrided material (increase of 10 percent at room temperature and 20 percent at 400 C).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: The strength of the hydrided tube (460 ppm H2) was greater than the unhydrided material (increase of 10 percent at room temperature and 20 percent at 400 C).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: The burst strengths were significantly higher than the tensile strength obtained in the ring tension test and this has been ascribed to the biaxial stress condition existing in the closed-end burst test.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: circumferential elongation to fracture is plotted in Fig. 7 as a function of hydrogen content

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: electrolytically hydrided tubes with uniformly distributed hydride were the most ductile, giving an adequate value of 10 percent up to this level of 330 ppm H2, before dropping to 2.5 percent at the 460-ppm H2 level

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: least ductile condition cold was with a hydride layer around the external tube surface and low ductility values (that is, 1.5 percent) have been obtained for hydrogen levels inside the tube of only ~70 ppm

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: Intermediate ductilities were obtained when the hydrogen was introduced by autoclaving in an aqueous LiOH solution forming a layer of highly concentrated platelets just inside the exposed external surface. Zero ductility was now obtained at the 330-ppm H2 level

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: ring-tension results showed higher ductilities than the tube-burst tests for all hydrogen contents, and much higher hydrogen levels (~700 ppm) were needed to embrittle the Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: At the higher temperatures of 300 to 350 C, the tube bulges locally and fractures, but the crack propagation is maintained within about l-in. length since greater energy is required for crack propagation at the higher temperature

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: Transverse section of failure in hydrided Zircaloy-2 tubing at room temperature. Absence of voids or separation in the matrix hydride platelets

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: Transverse section of failure in LiOH autoclaved Zircaloy-2 tubing at room temperature. Cracking starts in outer layers of highly concentrated platelets. H2 level = 820 ppm

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: Only occasionally, in the room temperature tests of the lower hydrogen levels (100 ppm), were voids seen in the remaining hydride platelets

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: The preferred orientation of these tubes has been described elsewhere. Briefly, the majority of the crystals are oriented with their (1010) poles axially although some have a (2130) pole orientation axially. The basal (000l) poles are aligned in the tangential directions with some spread on either side of this direction. A duplex component of (1 120) poles was found in the tangential direction implying that some basal poles have a radial alignment

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: Ring tension tests provide a good, rapid indication of transverse tensile properties in the unhydrided tubing but they are not nearly so sensitive to hydride embrittlement as the biaxially stressed, tube-burst test
